message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a prolonged QTc, which increases the risk of arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death. Sensorineural hearing loss is also associated with the congenital long QT syndrome. Oblique palpebral fissures suggest Down syndrome, brachial-femoral pulse delay suggests coarctation of the aorta, and subvalvular ventricular outflow obstruction murmur suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, but none of these conditions are directly related to prolonged QTc.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The episode of unconsciousness and the family history suggest a possible arrhythmia. A prolonged QTc interval can lead to syncope and sudden cardiac death. Sensorineural hearing loss is a common finding in patients with congenital long QT syndrome. Oblique palpebral fissures suggest Down syndrome. Brachial-femoral pulse delay suggests coarctation of the aorta. Subvalvular ventricular outflow obstruction murmur suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, but this is not associated with prolonged QT interval.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient likely has a long QT syndrome, which can cause sudden loss of consciousness and can be associated with sensorineural hearing loss. Oblique palpebral fissures suggest Down syndrome, brachial-femoral pulse delay suggests coarctation of the aorta, and subvalvular ventricular outflow obstruction murmur suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which are all less likely causes in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's QTc of 470 milliseconds indicates a prolonged QT interval, which can be a risk factor for sudden cardiac death. Prolonged QT syndrome can also cause sensorineural hearing loss, making option B the most likely additional finding. The other options are not related to prolonged QT syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged QTc interval suggests a potential risk for arrhythmia, particularly Torsades de Pointes. Among the options, sensorineural hearing loss is commonly associated with congenital long QT syndrome. Oblique palpebral fissures are associated with Down syndrome, brachial-femoral pulse delay with coarctation of the aorta, and subvalvular ventricular outflow obstruction murmur with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, none of which are suggested by the patient’s history or ECG findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged QTc interval suggests Long QT syndrome. Sensorineural hearing loss is a common finding in Long QT syndrome. All other options are not associated with Long QT syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged QTc interval suggests the possibility of long QT syndrome (LQTS), which is associated with sudden cardiac death. Sensorineural hearing loss may be an additional finding in patients with LQTS due to abnormalities in potassium channels in the inner ear. The other options are not specifically associated with LQTS.
